DOC.HEAD: PRECEDE BERN
France, Switzerland Freeze Noriega Bank Accounts
Eds: LEADS thruout to UPDATE with France freezing about $3.3 million of Noriega money. No pickup
With AM-Panama, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Authorities froze French bank accounts Wednesday holding about $3.3 million under the names of Panama's Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega and members of his family. Switzerland provisionally froze two bank accounts there. U.S. troops invaded Panama last week and deposed Noriega as leader. Noriega, who is wanted on U.S. drug-trafficking and money-laundering charges, is penned up in the Vatican Embassy in Panama City. Justice Department chief spokesman David Runkel said in Washington that U.S. officials believe Noriega hid at least $10 million in bank accounts in Switzerland, France, Luxembourg and Britain. Judge Patrick Fievet of the Paris Tribunal blocked the Noriegas from having access to accounts at the Banque Nationale de Paris and the Credit Industriel et Commerciale. He acted under a warrant issued Friday charging unidentified people with drug-trafficking and taking part in international financial operations related to illegal drugs. Investigators said the banks may have been used as transit points for funds destined for Luxembourg or Switzerland. The French customs and anti-drug investigation appears to have been based on a tip from the United States. In Bern, a statement issued by the Swiss Justice Ministry said a U.S. request to Switzerland charged Noriega with illegal drug trafficking by giving ``logistic support'' to Colombian drug lords' shipments to the United States. It said that according to U.S. authorities, some of the money Noriega received from the Colombians was paid into accounts in Switzerland. Ministry spokesman Joerg Kistler said the U.S.request included ``precise information'' on two accounts in banks in Zurich and Geneva. Authorities ordered a ``precautionary'' freeze on the accounts. Kistler refused to elaborate. Runkel said that based on records seized in Panama, U.S. officials think they can document that the money in the overseas accounts stemmed from Noriega drug dealing. Leaders of the so-called Group of Seven industrialized nations agreed at a Paris summit in July to cooperate more closely against the illegal drug trade and money-laundering. Noriega would be the biggest target of a joint investigation since the agreement. The G-7 countries include the United States, Britain, Canada, France, Japan, Italy, and West Germany.
